Source

Packages

Start by downloading the corresponding package for your configuration:

  • RHEL 6
  • RHEL 7

YUM Repositories

You can also install Qordoba via YUM; follow the instructions on the "Set Me Up" section on the page below.

  • RPM Repository

Installation

  1. Enable the EPEL repository

    Before installing Qordoba, you need to install the epel-release package for right version of your operating system, so that Qordoba can fetch all the required dependencies:

    $ EL_VERSION=`cat /etc/redhat-release | grep -oE '[0-9]+\.[0-9]+'` && \
  sudo yum install https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/epel-release-latest-${EL_VERSION%.*}.noarch.rpm

  2. Install Qordoba

    If you are downloading the package, execute:

    $ sudo yum install qordoba-community-edition-0.2.1.*.noarch.rpm --nogpgcheck

  3. Prepare your database

    Configure Qordoba so it can connect to your database. Qordoba supports both PostgreSQL 9.5+ and Cassandra 3.x.x as its datastore.

    If you are using Postgres, please provision a database and a user before starting Qordoba, ie:

    CREATE USER qordoba; CREATE DATABASE qordoba OWNER qordoba;

    Now, run the Qordoba migrations:

    $ qordoba migrations up [-c /path/to/qordoba.conf]

    Note: migrations should never be run concurrently; only one Qordoba nodes should be performing migrations at a time.

  4. Start Qordoba

    $ qordoba start [-c /path/to/qordoba.conf]

  5. Use Qordoba

    Qordoba is running:

    $ curl -i http://localhost:8001/

    Quickly learn how to use Qordoba with the 5-minute Quickstart.

Follow Up:

Get future release notes emailed to you.
